H0.text: Abiotic factors are the nonliving factors of an ecosystem, such as temperature, water, soil, and air.

H1.text: Nucleic factors are the nonliving factors of an ecosystem, exemplified by temperature, water, soil, and air.

H2.text: Conditional factors are the nonliving factors of an ecosystem, such as temperature, water, soil, and air.

H3.text: Diverse factors are the nonliving factors of an ecosystem, such as temperature, water, soil, and air.

A4.text: Abiotic factors can include water, light, radiation, temperature, humidity, atmosphere, acidity, salinity, precipitation, altitude, minerals, tides, rain, dissolved oxygen nutrients, and soil.

A5.text: All non-living components of an ecosystem, such as atmospheric conditions and water resources, are called abiotic components.
